data.title: CNY's 75 all-time greatest high school boys basketball players, in order
authors: Nolan Weidner and Charlie Miller | syracuse.com
data.text:
CNY's all-time greatest high school basketball players, in order

By Nolan Weidner and Charlie Miller

Nearly a year ago, we set out to compile a list of the best high school basketball players to ever come out of Central New York. We brainstormed with some of the top minds in the history of local hoops.

We enlisted the help of Hall of Fame coaches, athletic directors, players, sports writers and referees. We debated for months over who’s in, who’s out and where they rank.

The result is an impressive collection of the top 75 Section III players, in order.

What's the criteria to make this list? We considered high school performances, what the players did in college and, in many cases, pro basketball and beyond.

We know some will disagree over who we included or left off and where they’re ranked.

That's what makes this so fun. Let us know what you think in the comments section or email us at hssports@syracuse.com.

» Top 75 boys basketball players of all time from CNY high schools: Who got snubbed?

Don't Edit

Photo: Stephen Cannerelli

75: Jeff O'Connor

West Genesee

Class of 1994

Owned two Onondaga League records for 3-point shooting: most threes in a season (94) and most in his career (191)

Finished his high school career with 1,347 points

Played in every game during his four years at Niagara, averaging 7.8 points and about two 3-pointers per game.

also played lacrosse at West Genesee and Niagara.

Don't Edit

File photo

74: Tony Borges

Auburn

Class of 1992

Scored 1,069 career points as a four-year starter for the Maroons.

Led Auburn to consecutive Section III Class A championship games.

Was fifth-team, all-state selection as a junior.

Also starred at quarterback for Maroons football team.

Played one season at Collin Community College in Plano, Texas

Current men's basketball coach at Cayuga Community College.

Don't Edit

File photo

73: Ben Cronin

Henninger

Class of 2008

True 7-footer was three-year standout at Henninger, scoring 884 points and 506 blocked shots.

His blocks mark eclipsed school record of 290 set four years earlier by Andray Blatche.

Was named MVP of sectional basketball tournament after leading Black Knights past Utica Proctor for Class AA title.

Second-team all-state in Class AA and All-Central New York Player of the Year.

Averaged 19.1 points and 15.2 rebounds his senior season (Henninger went 21-3) and credited with 171 blocks.

Went to Michigan, where he was first recruit of new Wolverines coach John Beilien

Struggled with hip problems for two seasons and surgery cut short his basketball career as a college sophomore.

Don't Edit

Photo: David Lassman & Michelle Gabel

72: Matt Gorman

Watertown

Class of 2002

The 6-foot-9 center scored 1,207 career points and led Watertown to a Class A sectional championship in 2001 and a runner-up finish in 2002.

Averaged 19 points and 10 rebounds as a junior, when he was the All-Central New York Player of the Year and a third-team, all-state selection. Watertown was 23-1.

Scored 21 points per game and averaged 10 rebounds and 4 blocks as a senior, when the Cyclones went 22-1 and finished as the No. 8 team in the state. Was a first-team, All-CNY selection.

Played at Syracuse University from 2002-07, sitting out in '04-'05.

Member of SU's 2003 national championship team.

Scored 197 points and grabbed 142 rebounds in 75 games for the Orange.

Played professional basketball in Ireland and England.

Don't Edit

Don't Edit

Courtesy of Liverpool High School

71: Paul Seymour Jr.

Liverpool

Class of 1973

Son of late Syracuse Nationals star Paul Seymour scored 1,064 career points for the Warriors from 1970-73.

Was a two-time All-Onondaga League North Conference All-Star and was a co-captain on the 1973 Post-Standard Upstate All-Star team.

Scored 18.6 points per game as a junior and 20.1 as a senior. Averaged more than seven assists per game his senior season.

Played at Worcester (Mass.) Academy after high school.

Don't Edit

Newspaper archive

70: John Kobar

Bishop Ludden

Class of 1976

Scoring champion of the Central New York Cities League

Averaged 22.6 points per game in his senior year, including 46 points against Henninger. He also averaged 6 rebounds, 3 assists and 2 steals during his senior year.

Signed to play basketball at Wichita State. He played in all 28 games his freshman season and averaged about 6 points. He played in almost every game in his four years.

Don't Edit

Scott Schild | sschild@syracuse.

69: Nick Comenale

New York Mills

Class of 2014

Was voted Player of the Year in Class D after leading the Marauders to a state championship.

Scored 1,250 career points - averaging 24.4 in his senior season.

All-State selection his junior and senior seasons. First-team, All-Central New York as a senior.

Plays for Babson College and helped lead Beavers to 2017 national championship in Division III is a junior.

Was All-Northeast Region fourth-team selection as a junior, when he averaged 16 points, 5.4 rebounds and shot 43.8 percent from 3-point range (made 110 3-pointers).

Don't Edit

Courtesy of Liverpool High School

68: Fran D'Agata

Liverpool

Class of 1991

Scored 1,359 career points for the Warriors from 1987-91.

Was All-Central New York and sixth-team all-state honoree after senior season.

Helped lead Warriors to sectional Class A titles in 1988 and 1990.

Ended high school career with 179 3-pointers, which was a Section III record.

Played at Hamilton College from 1991-95

Scored 1,359 career points and set school record with 271 career 3-points. Was fourth in career assists with 542.

As senior helped lead Continentals to Sweet 16 of NCAA Division-III basketball tournament.

Don't Edit

Courtesy of Notre Dame

67: Bob Devins

Utica Notre Dame

Class of 1970

Scored 1,136 career points for the Jugglers.

Named first-team, all-state following senior season. Was on the same team with future Syracuse University star Dennis DuVal, whose number was recently retired by the Orange.

Led Notre Dame to a 19-2 record and final No. 3 state ranking his senior season.

The 6-foot-5 Devins scored 28.2 points per game in league play as a senior.

Was named to the Post-Standard Area All-Star team.

Scored 43 points in a game against Utica Proctor in 1970.

Coached the boys team at Notre Dame from 1980-84, guiding the team to a 64-30 overall record and three Section III B-2 titles.

Don't Edit

Don't Edit

File photo

66: Chuck Bisesi

St. Lucy's

Class of 1959

One of the stars of the former Parochial League, Bisesi scored 1,480 career points in four seasons at St. Lucy's.

Averaged 15 points per game as a freshman, 20 as a sophomore, 25 as a junior and 33 as a senior.

Set all-time Parochial League mark as a senior when he dropped 63 points on Most Holy Rosary.

Was a first-team, All-Parochial League as a junior and senior.

Went on to coach at the former Bishop Cunningham High School in Oswego. From 1980 to 1992 his teams won four Section III titles and the New York Class D title in 1985.

Don't Edit

Photo: Peter Chen

65: Deandre Preaster

Utica Proctor

Class of 2008

Two-sport athlete scored 1,352 career points while leading the Raiders to consecutive Section III basketball championships (2006 and 2007) and a runner-up finish in 2008.

The 6-foot-3, 200-pound forward was a three-time All-Central New York selection and twice was named Player of the Year.

All-state Class AA selection three straight years -- making sixth team in 2006, fourth team in 2007 and third team in 2008.

Also excelled in football and was offered a scholarship to Syracuse University as a wide receiver. Was a non-qualifier and instead ended up playing basketball at Mohawk Valley and Herkimer County community colleges.

Averaged 15.8 points and pulled down 13.3 rebounds per game in 2009-10 at Mohawk Valley

Scored 16.6 points and grabbed 10.9 rebounds per game at Herkimer the following year.

Don't Edit

Photo: Dick Blume

64: Tom Drumm

Bishop Grimes

Class of 1995

All-Central New York Player of the Year and first-team all-state selection in Class D after senior season.

Scored 19.5 points per game for Cobras, who went 23-3 and lost in state D semifinals.

Scored 1,865 career points for Grimes.

Was member of 1991-92 team that lost in state D final.

Don't Edit

Photo: Irena Pastorello

63: Latavia Escho

Henninger

Class of 2000

Scored 1,544 career points for the Black Knights from 1996-2000.

The 6-foot-6 Escho was twice an All-Central New York selection and was Player of the Year in 2000.

Averaged 28.9 points and 12 rebounds per game as a senior and 25.3 points and 12 rebounds as a junior.

Named to Class A all-state teams (fifth and sixth) for two seasons.

His 41 points against Corcoran in 2000 was a school record until Chris Turner surpassed it two years later.

Twice received honorable mention as a McDonald's High School All-American.

Signed with Rider College during senior season.

Don't Edit

Newspaper archive

62: Randy Jones

Bishop Ludden

Class of 1985

The 6-foot-6 big man led the Gaelic Knights to sectional Class A title as a senior.

Earned all-state honors in 1984-85 and was two-time All-CNY Cities League all-star.

Averaged 16.4 points and 9.5 rebounds as a junior in 1983-84, scoring a season-high 35 points against Henninger.

Averaged 15.7 points and 11 rebounds his senior season.

Don't Edit

Don't Edit

61: Richard McCormick

Henninger

Class of 1983

Two-time all-city guard for the Black Knights was fourth-team, all-state selection after averaging 18 points and seven assists as a senior.

The 6-foot-3 guard averaged 17.8 points as a junior.

Went to Marquette, where he played in 16 games in 1983-84 seasons before transferring to St. Bonaventure.

Played two seasons for the Bonnies and set a school record for 3-point accuracy (44.4 percent) by makings 92 of 207 attempts from 1986-88.

Averaged more than 14 points per game as a senior.

Don't Edit

Photo: Dennis Nett

60: Josh Wright

Utica Proctor

Class of 2004

Scored 1,944 career points at Utica Proctor, including a school-record 56 in one game against Berkshire.

Averaged 33.3 points per game as a senior, when he led Proctor to the Class AA sectional finals and was a first-team, all-state selection.

Was fifth-team, all-state as a junior when he averaged 25 points per game.

Was twice the Utica Dispatch-Observer Player of the Year and was two-time All-Central New York first-teamer.

Played at Syracuse University from 2004-08.

Scored 392 points (4.4 per game avg.) in career.

Left SU his senior season and finished collegiate career at the University of Ottawa in Canada.

Don't Edit

Newspaper archive

59: John Unger

North Syracuse

Class of 1967

Three-sport star scored 1,021 career points for the Northmen from 1964-67.

The 6-foot-3 forward averaged 20.2 points and 13 rebounds his senior season of 1966-67 and his 283 points led the league in scoring.

Was twice named a County League All-Star and was co-captain of the team his senior year.

Was a power-hitting catcher for the Syracuse University baseball team.

Signed in 1971 by the Chicago Cubs organization, but a leg injury ended his career during his rookie year.

Returned to North Syracuse and spent 33 years as a teacher and coach in the school district.

Coached varsity basketball for 20 seasons, and was first coach of combined Cicero-North Syracuse team.

Don't Edit

Photo: Peter Chen

58: Tommy Gunn

Corcoran

Class of 1999

Averaged 14.6 points, 8.6 rebounds and 2.3 assists his senior season for the Cougars, earning league MVP and all-state (10th team) honors.

Went to prep school at Bridgton Academy.

Played at Middle Tennessee State from 2001-04, where he was a two-time All-Sun Belt Conference first-team selection.

In 113 games, Gunn scored 1,528 career points. He averaged 16 points as a senior and 15.9 as a junior.

Don't Edit

Photo: John Berry

57: Derek Jackson

Corcoran

Class of 1991

Scored 1,005 career points for the Cougars.

Was a 1991 All-Central New York selection after senior season in which he scored 19.3 points per game and was assist leader on team that went 20-3.

Went to Boston College, where he played in 32 games in two seasons and scored 50 points and had 18 assists.

Transferred to Florida Atlantic, where he scored 370 points and accumulated 163 assists in 51 games over two seasons.

Is currently head boys basketball coach at Nottingham High School.

Don't Edit

Don't Edit

Newspaper archive

56: Scott Wilson

Lyme

Class of 1982

Scored 2,391 career points, which at the time was a state record. That total is now third highest in Section III history behind Bernard Blunt and Greg Paulus.

Scored 74 points in a game against Copenhagen during his senior season, in which he reportedly averaged 42.2 points, 20 rebounds and 11 assists.

Went to Jefferson Community College, where he scored 1,249 points in two seasons to become the program's all-time scoring leader.

Played at Ithaca College, where he averaged 15.3 points and 4.2 rebounds a game his junior season. Knee problems ended his collegiate career early in his senior season.

Don't Edit

File photo

55: Latavius Murray

Onondaga

Class of 2008

Tigers' football star, whose No. 28 is retired by the school, also was an all-state basketball player.

Scored 1,635 career points from 2004-08.

Was first-team, all-state Class C selection in 2006-07 and 2007-08.

All-Central New York selection who averaged 17.7 points his senior season.

Played college football at Central Florida, where he rushed for 2,424 career yards (5.4 average) and caught passes for 524 yards. Was All-Conference USA first-team choice his senior season of 2012.

Was sixth-round selection of Oakland Raiders in the 2013 NFL draft.

Currently a starting running back for the Minnesota Vikings.

Don't Edit

54: Gus Castellini

Solvay

Class of 1952

The 6-foot-3 forward scored a career 1,004 points, many of them with an unusual "overhead" set shot.

As a senior in 1951-52, Castellini scored an Onondaga League record 380 points - in 10 games. Included in his total were efforts of 48 and 51 points, both at the expense of North Syracuse.

Defeated powerful Central Tech and its star, Manny Breland, on the way to a sectional title game loss at the hands of Whitesboro.

Went to Syracuse University, where he played three varsity seasons from 1953-56, mostly as a reserve behind the great Vinnie Cohen and Jim Brown.

Don't Edit

Provided photo

53: Pete Schmid

Sacred Heart

Class of 1968

Considered one of the best to come out of basketball powerhouse Sacred Heart.

Schmid was a 6-foot-5 center who earned berths on the Post-Standard All-Star teams in 1967 and 1968.

Played at Boston College from 1968-72

Scored 705 career points in 64 games over three varsity seasons (1969-72) and averaged 14 points per game as a senior.

Don't Edit

Photo: Stephen D. Cannerelli

52: Craig Kowadla

Westhill

Class of 1991

Scored 1,966 career points at Westhill from 1986-91 and remains the school's all-time leader.

First-team, all-state Class C-D selection in 1990-91.

All-Central New York selection.

Played at LaFayette College from 1992-96, scoring 1,413 career points.

Led the Leopards in scoring and was team captain his junior and senior seasons.

Patriot League all-star as a senior.

Don't Edit

Don't Edit

File photo

51: Adam Stockwell

Belleville-Henderson Central

Class of 1992

Scored 2,020 points from 1988-92.

Earned first-team, all-state honors in Class D after 1991-92 season.

Combined with his father, Jim, to form only father-son duo to each surpass 2,000 career points in state basketball.

Played at Le Moyne College from 1992-96, where as a senior he led Dolphins to school-best 24-6 mark and NCAA Division-II playoffs.

Averaged 21.1 points and 5.6 rebounds his senior season.

Received honorable mention All-American.

Played professionally in Northern Ireland after college.

Went on to successful coaching career and is currently in his seventh season as head basketball coach at Hamilton College.

Don't Edit

Provided archive

50: Jim Stockwell

Union Academy, Belleville

Class of 1969

Scored 2,108 career points and hauled down 1,402 rebounds for the powerful Black Knights, who won a state-record 104 consecutive games from 1966-71.

The 6-foot-3 point guard led the Knights to sectional Class D titles in 1967, 68 and 69, going a combined 64-0 in those seasons.

Earned third-team, all-state honors after 1968-69 season.

Was a member of the 1968-69 Prep All-American Basketball Team.

With his son, Adam, formed the only father-son duo to each surpass 2,000-point scoring mark in state.

Don't Edit

Newspaper archive

49: Gallagher Driscoll

Bishop Ludden

Class of 1988

Earned All-CNY and all-state (12th team) honors after scoring 20.3 points per game his senior season. Was 7-for-7 from 3-point line in first half vs. Central Square.

Led Bishop Ludden to a 57-13 record in three years as a starter.

Unaninous Metro League all-star helped Ludden reach 1987 state Class A championship game against Shenendehowa (69-52 loss) with playoff victories over Binghamton and Buffalo Nichols.

Played four years at the College of St. Rose Albany, where he scored 972 points, dished off 878 assists and hauled in 391 steals in four seasons from 1988-92.

As senior, led Golden Knights to a 24-7 record and NCAA Division II tournament.

Inducted into St. Rose's Hall of Fame in 2007.

Don't Edit

Photo: Gloria Wright

48: Chris Turner

Henninger

Class of 2002

Scored 1,119 career points for the Black Knights - in two varsity seasons.

Was state's Class A co-Player of the Year after senior season in which he led Henninger to the state public schools championship in Class A and to Federation Tournament runner-up spot after 61-53 loss to Rice High School.

Was named public school tourney MVP after scoring 38 points and pulling down 19 rebounds in a 71-56 win over Rochester McQuaid.

Was All-Central New York Player of the Year as senior, averaging 26.7 points and 14 rebounds per game.

Also named to All-CNY football first team as tight end.

Played football at Wagner College from 2003-06

Set numerous Wagner receiving marks - including career marks of 213 receptions, 2,863 receiving yards and 33 TD passes. Holds single-game marks of 4 receiving TDs, 15 catches and 202 yards.

Don't Edit

Billy McBride

47: Billy McBride

Central Tech

Class of 1974

An All-City selection in both football and basketball.

Also earned All-Upstate honors in football.

Attended Tennessee State and played basketball and football.

Drafted by the NFL's San Francisco 49ers.

Played six seasons in the Canadian Football League as a defensive back, for Saskatchewan, Brittish Columbia and Ottawa. He is credited with 16 interceptions.

Member of the Greater Syracuse Sports Hall of Fame.

Don't Edit

Don't Edit

Photo courtesy of Providence College

46: Steve Wright

Fowler

Class of 1984

First-team, all-state selection in his senior season, 1983-84, when he led Fowler to a 24-1 season.

6-foot-9 center turned down scholarship offer at Syracuse University to attend Providence, where he played four seasons from 1984-88.

Scored 1,060 career points for the Friars and grabbed 672 rebounds in 123 games.

Don't Edit

Photo: Dick Blume

45: Maurice Brown

Henninger

Class of 1997

Scored 1,749 career points for the Black Knights, a school record.

Second-team, all-state selection in 1995-96, and first-team choice in 1996-97.

Two-time All-Central New York Player of the Year - 1996 and 1997.

Led Black Knights to three consecutive Section III titles in Class A and two trips to the state semifinals.

Averaged 23 points per game in senior season.

Signed with Rutgers initially, but ended up transferring to Illinois-Chicago, where he ended up playing two seasons (1999-2001) and scored 585 points (9.9 avg.) and grabbing 368 rebounds (6.2 avg.).

Finished collegiate career at Division-II Roberts Wesleyan College.

Don't Edit

Photo: Suzanne Dunn

44: Paul Seymour III

Liverpool

Class of 1999

Set career scoring mark at Liverpool with 1,606 career points from 1994-99.

Led Warriors with 24 points per game in 1998-99 season when team just missed trip to state final four.

Was 1999 All-Central New York player of the year and third-team, all-state Class A selection.

Grandson of former Syracuse Nats great Paul Seymour.

Played at Boston University from 1999-2003, scoring 1,136 career points in 120 games.

Career scoring average of 9.5 points per game at BU.

Don't Edit

File photo

43: Scott Knapp

Vernon-Verona-Sherrill

Class of 1997

Playing for his father, legendary coach Al Knapp, Scott scored 1,897 career points for the Red Devils from 1994-97

First-team, all-state in Class B after 1996-97 season.

Career 288 3-pointers listed as fourth, all-time, by NYSPHSAA, and his 108 in 96-97 season is considered second-most.

Played college basketball at Siena College from 1997-2001 and ended as one of the school's all-time 3-point and free-throw shooters.

Scored 1,381 points, including a (still) school-record 293 3-pointers and 393 assists.

His 89.1 percent career FT percentage remains a school record.

Played in the former Continental Basketball Association for the Rockford (Ill.) Lightning.

Don't Edit

42: Vic Hanson

Central Tech

Class of 1923

Hanson, a Watertown native, was a three-sport star in football, basketball and baseball at Syracuse Central and Manlius Military Academy.

He once scored 31 of his team's 32 points in a high school game.

Went on to star in three sports at Syracuse University, where he captained three teams and was called SU's greatest all-around athlete by legendary sportswriter Grantland Rice.

The 1925-26 Orange basketball team went 19-1 and won the Helms Athletic Foundation National Championship.

In 1926-27, his senior year, Hanson scored 280 points, a single-season SU record that stood until 1946. He also won national player of the year honors.

Earned All-American status in football (end) and basketball at SU and is in both the National Basketball Hall of Fame and College Football Hall of Fame.

Signed by the New York Yankees to play baseball after college.

Basketball No. 8 is retired by SU.

Don't Edit

Don't Edit

41: Pat Stark

Syracuse Vocational

Class of 1949

Was three-sport star at Vocational who played both football and basketball at Syracuse University.

In high school, scored a then-state record 78 points in one game against Smith Technical in 1949.

Earned All-City honors in basketball in 1948 and 1949.

After a year at Virginia Military Academy, Stark went to Syracuse University to play football and basketball.

Scored 161 points in two seasons as SU basketball player.

In football, Stark won three varsity letters at SU and earned All-East status his junior and senior seasons at quarterback.

Passed for more than 1,000 yards as junior and senior and completed 19 TD passes.

Led the Orange to the Orange Bowl in 1953, a 61-6 loss to Alabama.

Was a second-round choice of the Pittsburgh Steelers in the 1954 NFL draft.

Coached football at SU under Ben Schwartzwalder for several years and was head coach for combined 20 seasons at Harvard and University of Rochester.

Don't Edit

File photo

40: Pat Campolieta

Bishop Ludden

Class of 1998

Scored 1,124 career points for Gaelic Knights

Earned All-State and All-Central New York honors after his senior season in which he averaged 21 points, 10 rebounds and five assists.

The 6-foot-6 forward led Ludden to three consecutive sectional Class C titles.

Played at Colgate from 1998-2002.

Two-time captain for Raiders led team in scoring four straight seasons.

Finished with 1,616 career points, 698 rebounds, 250 assists and 193 steals (school record).

Was four-time All-Patriot League choice (first-team three years) and three-time team MVP.

One of three Colgate players (with Adonal Foyle and Tucker Neale) named to Patriot League Men's Basketball 25th Anniversary Team in 2015.

Don't Edit

39: George Deptula

Christian Brothers Academy

Class of 1960

Scored 1,337 career points at CBA, second only to Greg Paulus (2,399) in school history.

Was a three-time All-City selection from 1958-60.

Averaged 20.1 points per game as a sophomore and led the city league in scoring his junior and senior seasons.

Deptula also was an All-City baseball player two seasons and was a good receiver on powerful Golden Tornadoes football teams.

Went to Holy Cross on a basketball scholarship and played for two seasons.

Don't Edit

Photo: Stephen D. Cannerelli

38: DaJuan Coleman

Jamesville-DeWitt

Class of 2012

Scored 1,838 career points in four seasons at J-D

Was four-time all-state selection, and a first-team choice his final three seasons.

State's Class A Player of the Year and Mr. Basketball after 2011-12 season.

Helped lead Red Rams to consecutive state Class A titles from 2009-11.

The 6-foot-9 center was named a McDonald's High School All-American after senior season.

Played at Syracuse University from 2012-2017, missing 2014-15 season with knee injury.

Scored 396 points (5.1 average) and grabbed 343 rebounds (4.4 avg.) in 78 games.

Don't Edit

File photo

37: Ronnie Leggette

Nottingham

Class of 1982

Star of Nottingham's 1982 Class B state and federation championship team that went 26-1.

Leggette was MVP of the 1982 state tournament, and he scored 32 points in the Bulldogs' federation tourney win over St. Agnes.

Averaged 19.1 points as a senior and was all-state selection.

Scored 1,264 career points as a Bulldog.

Went on to play at West Virginia State in 1986-87, scoring 769 career points in two seasons.

Was seventh-round selection of Golden State Warriors in 1987 NBA draft.

Inducted into college's Hall of Fame.

Don't Edit

Don't Edit

Photo: Dennis Nett

36: Andy Rautins

Jamesville-DeWitt

Class of 2005

Helped lead J-D to 2004 state Class A championship (public school and federation) and 29-0 record.

Scored 1,005 career points for Red Rams and in 2004-05 was named first-team, all-state, and to All-Central New York first team.

Followed in footsteps of father, Leo Rautins, and played at Syracuse University from 2005-10 (missed 2007-08 season with knee injury).

Scored 1,121 career points (8.8 per game) and connected on 282 3-pointers for Orange.

As senior, averaged 12.1 ppg and earned second-team, All-Big East honors.

Selected by New York Knicks in second round of 2010 NBA draft.

Played for Canadian National Basketball Team.

Currently playing pro basketball in Turkey and has spent time in NBA's D-League and with various European teams.

Don't Edit

Photo: Suzanne Dunn

35: Scott Ungerer

Westhill

Class of 1998

Scored 1,250 points from 1994-98 while leading Warriors to Class B state championship in 1997 and runner-up finish in 1998.

Class B all-state selection after 1997-98 season.

All-Central New York Player of the Year in 1998.

Played college basketball at Richmond, where he averaged 6.4 points in 120 games from 1998-2002.

Don't Edit

Photo: Harry DiOrio

34: Len Rauch

Bishop Ludden

Class of 1987

Starred in basketball and baseball for the Gaelic Knights.

Two-time All-City selection and All-State honoree, helped lead Ludden to the 1987 state championship game where the Gaelic Knights lost to Shenendehowa. On the way, Ludden defeated Buffalo Nichols, with Christian Laettner, and Binghamton, with star King Rice. Rauch scored 31 points in the 64-50 win over Binghamton.

Played both sports at Le Moyne College, including two seasons of baseball where to Dolphins played in the NCAA regional finals.

Set school all-time career scoring record (1,876 points) in 1991 that stood for 19 seasons. Also left as Le Moyne's top rebounder (1,151 boards).

In 1991 he toured with the Harlem Globetrotters as a member of the Boston Shamrocks.

Was inducted into the LeMoyne College Hall of Fame in 2001.

Inducted into the Syracuse Sports Hall of Fame in 2010.

Don't Edit

Photo: Dennis Nett

33: Manny Breland

Central Tech

Class of 1952

Four-time All-City selection from 1949-52.

Attended Syracuse University and was leading scorer on freshman team in 1953-54, averaging 9.8 points per game.

In 1957, Breland helped lead the Orange to the NCAA East Regional final.

Despite missing his junior season due to illness, Breland scored 538 career points.

Was longtime teacher, coach and administrator for Syracuse Schools, and led Central Tech to sectional basketball championships in 1968 and 1971.

Member of Greater Syracuse Sports Hall of Fame.

Don't Edit

Photo: Gary Walts

32: Jordan Roland

Westhill

Class of 2015

Two-time Class B state player of the year for Warriors, who won state championships in 2013-14 and 2014-15.

Scored 1,863 career points and was All-Central New York player of the year twice.

Scored 41 points in 2014 state title game blowout of Olean, just six shy of tournament record held by Bernard Blunt and Adonal Foyle.

Went to George Washington for two seasons and is sitting out this winter after transferring to Northeastern.

Don't Edit

Don't Edit

Provided archive

31: Mike Hanley

Sacred Heart

Class of 1972

All-state small schools selection 1971-72

Played at Niagara from 1972-77. The 6-9 Hanley played in 78 games, averaging 10.6 for his career. Averaged 12.8 his junior season and 11.6 as a senior.

Was a fifth-round selection of the Buffalo Braves in the 1977 NBA draft.

Inducted into the Niagara Hall of Fame in 1986.

Don't Edit

Newspaper archive

30: Roosevelt 'Pony' Bullock

Nottingham

Class of 1982

Member of Nottingham's 1982 state Class B championship team, averaging about 17 points per game for the Bulldogs.

Went to Potsdam where he played for teams that went 107-17 over four years and won a Division III national championship in 1985-86 with a 32-0 record.

Was most valuable player of 1986 tournament and was named first-team All-American for the 1985-86 season.

Don't Edit

Photo: Toren Beasley

29: Matt Roe

Fayetteville-Manlius

Class of 1986

Scored 1,127 career points for the Hornets from 1983-86 to leave as F-M's all-time scoring leader.

Played at Syracuse University from 1986-89, scoring 769 points in three seasons and averaging 11 points per game as a junior.

Transferred to Maryland, where he scored 497 points and averaged 17.8 points in 28 games.

Played professionally in the Continental Basketball Association and in Europe from 1991 to 1997.

Greater Syracuse Sports Hall of Fame

27: Ormie Spencer

St. Lucy's

Class of 1954

St. Lucy's basketball star who, as a freshman, scored 45 points in Parochial League playoff game in 1951 against St. Patrick's.

First freshman ever to make first team All-Parochial League.

Averaged 20.4 points per game during 1952-53 season as he led St. Lucy's to the Parochial League's first ever undefeated season (16-0 in the league). The team finished 23-1, with its only loss coming at the season-ending Eastern States Catholic Invitational Tournament in Newport, R.I.

Became Syracuse police officer, but died in 1964 in an off-duty car accident on Rt. 31.

City of Syracuse Park named after him.

Member of Greater Syracuse Sports Hall of Fame.

26: Craig Caldwell

Class of 1991

Scored 1,688 career points for the Bulldogs in six varsity seasons from 1985-91

Named state's Class B Player of the Year after leading Nottingham to Class B state public school and federation championships in senior season.

Also member of 1987 state Class B public and federation championship team.

Set sectional record for games played (131) and 3-pointers (168) in career.

Three-time All-Central New York selection, and captain of 1991 team.

Played at Cleveland State from 1991-95.

In 110 games, scored 983 career points (8.9 avg.), 455 assists (4.1) and 272 rebounds (2.5) for the Vikings.

Courtesy of New Mexico State University

25: Roy Neal

Central Tech

Class of 1968

Three-year starter on Tech teams and averaged 22.6 points per game on 21-1 team that won city and Section III championships.

Selected to the Pepsi Cola All-American Team after his senior season by Coaches and Athlete Magazine. In 1967-1968, Neal was first team all-state in basketball and was a member of the first-ever Parade Magazine All-American scholastic team.

Went to New Mexico State where he played for Lou Henson, and with Syracuse native Jimmy Collins, helping to lead the Aggies (28-3) to the NCAA Final Four in 1969-70 and a third-place finish as a sophomore. The next season, New Mexico State finished 19-8 to earn another NCAA invitation. Neal was a team captain his senior year, 1971-72, but his career was cut short by a knee injury.

Member of Greater Syracuse Sports Hall of Fame.

Played at Providence from 1992-96, scoring 1,163 career points in 104 starts. Was a member of the Friars 1994 Big East championship team.

12: Earl Belcher

Christian Brothers Academy

Class of 1977

Originally wanted to be a pro golfer and didn't concentrate on basketball until ninth grade.

Led the Brothers to consecutive league and sectional championships in 1975-76 and 1976-77.

As a junior, scored 16.5 points per game and averaged nearly eight rebounds for the 19-3 Brothers.

His senior year, those averages rose to 27.6 points and 14 rebounds as Belcher was named All-Upstate and third-team All-State.

Played for Coach Jim Satalin at St. Bonaventure and scored 2,077 career points.

Was two-time Eastern Eight (now Atlantic-10) Player of the Year.

Taken in fourth round of 1981 NBA draft by the San Antonio Spurs.

His pro career was cut short by an ankle injury.

Member of Greater Syracuse Sports Hall of Fame.

Averaged 9.3 points and 5.1 assists in 129 games.

10: Dale Shackelford

Utica Notre Dame

Class of 1975

Was high school star at Notre Dame, playing all four varsity seasons. Led the Central Oneida League in scoring as a sophomore, averaging 18.4 points per game. Left Notre Dame in 1975 as the Jugglers' all-time leading scorer, with 1,191 points. Shackleford led his team to the Section III championship, and was a second-team, all-state selection.

Rated among the top 50 high school players by Street And Smith, Shackleford was recruited by more than 200 Division I colleges according to the Greater Utica Sports Hall of Fame.

Played forward at Syracuse University from 1975-79, where he was a four-year starter and averaged 12.8 points and 7.3 rebounds per game. At 6-foot-6, played guard and forward for coach Roy Danforth.

Taken by Phoenix Suns in sixth round of 1979 NBA draft. Never played in the NBA but was professional in Chile, Italy and England, where he became a star.

Member of Greater Utica Sports Hall of Fame.

9: Joe Reddick

Vocational Tech, Corcoran

Class of 1967

Helped lead Corcoran to a 28-2 record in the new school's first two basketball seasons.

Was a two-time CNY Cities League first-team all-star in 1965-66 and 1966-67.

Scored 22.1 points per game in his senior year, leading Corcoran to a Section III Class A title.

Scored 15.2 points per game as a junior while directing Corcoran's attack as point guard.

Was named to the All-Central New York basketball team in 1967.

Played at Albany State College, an NAIA school in Georgia.

Sixteenth-round choice in the 1972 American Basketball Association draft by the Dallas Chaparrals, the forerunners of the NBA's San Antonio Spurs.

8: Gene Fisch

Sacred Heart

Class of 1961

Considered by many to be the greatest ever to play in the city's Parochial League despite being just 5-foot-9. Came to the United States in 1949 as a Polish Displaced Person.

Was Parochial League all-star four seasons at Sacred Heart, which won two league titles in that stretch.

Also starred in track and baseball at Sacred Heart. Was a third baseman/shortstop good enough to receive professional offers from several major league teams. Chose instead to head to New York University to play basketball.

Starting guard for three years on nationally ranked NYU teams. Played against Syracuse team with Dave Bing and Jim Boeheim in NIT; lost to Duke in regional final. Broke freshman scoring record held by Cal Ramsey (New York Knicks).

Member of Greater Syracuse Sports Hall of Fame.

Was New York's Mr. Basketball as senior and McDonald's All-American.

Returned to Syracuse to play QB for the Orange in a graduate season.

Asst. basketball coach six years under Thad Matta at The Ohio State University.

13-year NBA career after being first-round choice by Golden State Warriors in 1997. Played 733 games.

2: Larry Costello

Minoa

Class of 1949

'The Minoa Comet' graduated from high school in 1949 as a three-sport star and headed to Niagara

Avg. 15 ppg for Niagara and led team to NIT

Scored 1,275 career points in three seasons, was All-American

Drafted in the second round by the Philadelphia Warriors. Played there and Syracuse Nationals and 76ers.

Over 12 seasons, scored 8,622 points in 706 regular-season games, had a 12.2 average and 3,215 assists. He added 592 points in 52 playoff games for an 11.4 average. Won the 1967 NBA title with the 76ers. Played in five NBA All-Star games and twice led the league in foul shooting.

Coached expansion Milwaukee Bucks - 9 seasons, and won NBA title in 1970-71 (Kareem Abdul-Jabbar).

1: Jimmy Collins

Vocational Tech, Corcoran

Class of 1966

Three-time All-City player.

At 6-3, Collins was a prolific scorer and rebounder.

Played at New Mexico State and led his team to the Final Four in 1970 under Lou Henson.

Averaged 24 points per game as a senior and was named an All-American.

Was a first-round pick of the Chicago Bulls (11th overall) in 1970.

Played two seasons in the NBA before entering his coaching career, most notably as an assistant to Henson at Illinois and head coach at the University of Illinois at Chicago.

Member of the Greater Syracuse Sports Hall of Fame.
